intro: Limodorum trabutianum var. brulloi, commonly known as the Brullo's lily of the valley, is a rare and delicate flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of southern Italy. It belongs to the family Asparagaceae and is characterized by its bell-shaped, white or pale pink flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant has narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are arranged in a rosette at the base, and it typically grows in shaded, moist environments. Its botanical significance lies in its limited distribution and its role in the biodiversity of its native habitat. Due to its rarity, it is often protected and requires specific conditions to thrive.
